newsitem.title: BANGLADESH: Bangladesh awaits experts to put out gas field fire.
newsitem.headline: Bangladesh awaits experts to put out gas field fire.

text.p: Fire-fighting experts from Singapore and the United States were on their way to Bangladesh on Monday to battle a raging fire at a gas field where U.S. firm Occidental Petroleum Corp began drilling this month.
"They are expected any moment and will immediately try to extinguish the blaze," an official in northeastern Moulvi Bazar district, where the field is located, told reporters on Monday.
Officials with the state-owned oil and gas company Petrobangla said the government was keeping a chartered plane on standby to fly the foreign experts to the blazing field.
Four Bangladeshis were injured in the fire, which broke out on a rig at the drilling site at the Magurchhara gas field after an explosion early on Sunday.

Energy Ministry officials said the accident occurred when the rig's pipeline hit a "trap gas" layer at a depth of 840 metres (2,755 feet), destroying all the equipment and sending flames shooting high into the air.
The Petrobangla officials said Occidental was drilling a development well for gas in the area, which they believed holds substantial reserves of hydrocarbons.

Prime Minister Sheikh Hasina, due to return home on Monday from Istanbul where she attended the Developing-8 Islamic summit, has ordered "immediate steps" to put out the fire and investigate the cause, state-run Radio Bangladesh said.

The radio quoted unidentified Occidental officials in Moulvi Bazar as saying that "all measures have been taken to extinguish the fire". Occidental officials in Dhaka could not be reached for comment.
Experts with fire fighting equipment from Singapore were due to arrive on Monday to try to extinguish the blaze, Energy Secretary Tawfiq-e-Elahi Chowdhury told Reuters.
He said another expert team from Occidental's headquarters in Houston, Texas, would arrive shortly to assess the extent of damage and find out when drilling could be resumed.
Petrobangla chairman Mosharraf Hossain told Reuters on Sunday night that the fire was caused by leakage.
"We are uncertain when drilling will resume but expect the blaze will die down soon," he said.

Journalists said the fire had spread over a two km (1.2 mile) area around the gas field, 20 km (12 miles) from Moulvi Bazar. Police surrounded the area and prohibited visits except by experts and officials.
Workers at two nearby tea gardens and thousands of villagers fled in panic, they said. Railway tracks passing by the gas field also caught fire, disrupting train services.
Petrobangla officials told newspapers on Sunday night that there was no cause for panic or too much concern. "Things will come under control soon," one said.

Occidental won the right to explore for hydrocarbons in the Sylhet region bordering India's Meghalaya and Assam states and began drilling in the field on June 2. It has a production sharing contract with the Bangladesh government.
Occidental said it would spend up to $100 million in exploring three out of 23 blocs that Bangladesh has earmarked for foreign firms.
